data.title: Terminal's sendText adds extra empty lines in CRLF mode on Windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hi,
Here is the description of my findings. If it's not complete I can add what's needed. 
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.1 (9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e, 2016-10-13T16:21:53.542Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: alefragnani.Bookmarks-0.9.2, christian-kohler.path-intellisense-1.1.0, donjayamanne.githistory-0.1.0, Ionide.Ionide-FAKE-1.1.0, Ionide.Ionide-fsharp-2.8.8, Ionide.Ionide-Paket-1.3.2, mohsen1.prettify-json-0.0.3, ms-vscode.csharp-1.4.1, ms-vscode.PowerShell-0.7.2, ms-vscode.Theme-1337-0.1.2, robertohuertasm.vscode-icons-3.0.7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Get Ionide-fsharp addon
2. Create .fsx file (in CRLF mode)
3. Enter valid F# multi-line value, for example:

``` fsharp
"(* some text
on multiple
lines in comment*)"
```
1. Select typed text
2. Press Alt-Enter -> which is bound to command FSI: Send selection
3. See FSI terminal opens and prints out the selected text

The problem is that when file is in CRLF mode - terminal outputs extra lines, when in LF mode - terminal outputs the same text that was sent to it. 

I tracked it down in the Ionide-fsharp plugin to make sure that it is not the plugin messes things up. 
Here's selected text:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3036330/19832186/301f0cec-9e1d-11e6-965c-73e2912f49be.png)

Next the point in code where the text gets sent to Terminal object (which is `fp` on the screen):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3036330/19832194/56db0552-9e1d-11e6-904a-4a98dd5fd3cb.png)

The `msg_1` variable is evaluated to "            @\"(\* starts\r\n            let x = 10\r\n            *)\" \n;;\n"

This is what gets echoed: 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3036330/19832214/ae867372-9e1d-11e6-89eb-ec9aca680182.png)

You can see that it's got empty lines between the ones which were sent.

If I change the file to LF mode and perform same actions I get correct result: 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3036330/19832222/13de5f28-9e1e-11e6-9d68-b4390852447b.png)

Thanks

data.title: Feature request: lock ranges of the TextEditor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Request: provide API support to lock arbitrary ranges in the editor; i.e. make them read-only so the user and extensions cannot change the text within the region. This feature is supported by emacs (see [inhibit-read-only](https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/elisp/Read-Only-Buffers.html) and [this](http://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/76531/emacs-make-portion-of-buffer-readonly)). And it is useful for the extension I am writing for the Coq Proof Assistant: where editing a line that has already been interpreted causes the interpreter to roll back its state (potentially losing many minutes, sometimes an hour or so, of processing).

Now that I've made the request, I do have reservations about it being abused by extensions. So I think it would be prudent to also give the user the option to manually unlock any region and to globally disable the feature.

data.title: import completion should not triggered by dot
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows Server 2012 R2

Steps to Reproduce:

```
// type the following
import { something } form '[cursor here]

// then type in a dot (".")
```

expected: no completion. Users may want to do ".." for parent folder.
actual: completion triggered and list installed npm packages

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3254987/19831903/3911615e-9dca-11e6-8d32-c181e3e84a6e.png)

So what happen is if user wants to reference parent folder (".."), it will end up like this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3254987/19831910/59d135ea-9dca-11e6-8621-d1db245464bd.png)

data.title: Viewport for Extensions doesn't scale on high resolution displays
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Anniversary Update
- Device: Dell XPS 9350 QHD IPS (3200 x 1800)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VSCode
2. Change into the **Extensions** context
3. Perform an extension search, and select one
4. Use `CTRL + +` to increase the editor font size
5. Notice the poor scaling of the description area of the extension viewport (screenshot included below)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/466713/19831585/4152644a-9dd3-11e6-83be-5558d6f02441.png)

Cheers,
**Trevor Sullivan**
Docker Captain
Microsoft MVP: Cloud & Data Center Management
https://trevorsullivan.net
https://twitter.com/pcgeek86

data.title: CTRL + ALT + ENTER not working to Replace All
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Anniversary Update

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Perform a regex search/replace using `CTRL + H`
2. Press `CTRL + ALT + ENTER` to perform the replacement operation
3. The replacement operation does not occur

**NOTE**: When I use the mouse to hover over the **Replace All** button, it specifically mentions a `CTRL + ALT + ENTER` keyboard shortcut, hence the expectation is that, that keyboard shortcut would invoke the Replace All operation.

Cheers,
**Trevor Sullivan**
Docker Captain
Microsoft MVP: Cloud & Data Center Management
https://trevorsullivan.net
https://twitter.com/pcgeek86

data.title: VSCode is wiping out my search

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Anniversary Update

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start with an empty text file
2. Perform a regex search / replace (`CTRL + H`), for example `an$`
3. Paste in some text, where the _end_ of the text matches the search in step 1 (eg. `Trevor Sullivan`)
4. Hit `CTRL + H` to perform another search / replace
5. The regex search you performed is replaced with the word directly preceding the matching text

Let me know if you need help reproducing this behavior. I was able to do it myself several times.

Cheers,
**Trevor Sullivan**
Docker Captain
Microsoft MVP: Cloud & Data Center Management
https://trevorsullivan.net
https://twitter.com/pcgeek86

data.title: Fail to launch integrated terminal in a folder its name contains a non-ASCII character

data.title: launchservicesd CPU usage on MacOS Sierra
data.body:
I have been seeing this for at least few days but I just made the connection to vscode. Possibly since updating to 10.12.1. Would be great if someone else can try to repro.

I'll have several instances of Insiders open, not doing anything unusual, then notice that I'm using a ton of CPU of launchservicesd, Dock, and loginwindow.

Like this -
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19825999/22a0ac7a-9d36-11e6-829f-3834ba2af521.png)

The flat part of this graph, I was not touching the computer. When it goes up, I opened one more vscode instance. Then I cmd+q the whole thing and it all goes away.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19826004/31191580-9d36-11e6-82b5-30d3c64a401e.png)

And those processes are not used so much anymore
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19826002/2c626bc2-9d36-11e6-8956-b16cb26a7b29.png)

The next plateau is opening some project in insiders, and a few empty workspaces
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19826021/801e74c2-9d36-11e6-9f86-4ce2e94ca94e.png)

And closing that, then there is a small spike at the right - that's opening the same project and empty workspaces in stable Code, and it stays pretty flat after this.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19826032/afaaa4d6-9d36-11e6-86a7-75fee7b1ac6b.png)

This is with four empty workspaces open, closing them slowly one by one - 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19826080/b0574942-9d37-11e6-9b39-5aeaba3c31c3.png)

I can't find anything relevant about these processes. I can't repro with atom or atom beta, but they are using earlier electron versions.

data.title: Stack trace doesn't show up (in a very specific case)
data.body:
First off, this reproes in 1.6.1 and 1.7-insiders
- Open a new vs code window, because this only reproes in the first debugging session
- Open the file explorer in the sidebar
- Hide the sidebar (if the debug panel was the open pane when hiding it, this doesn't repro)
- Start debugging
- Hit a breakpoint
- Open the debug panel
- There is no stack trace

If you step, the stack trace and everything works as normal. If you do anything different from those steps, it doesn't repro. But with those steps it happens 100% of the time on OSX and Windows.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19825818/4a55840a-9d33-11e6-8bae-cdf6ceb3094d.png)

data.title: Debug adapter type traceability
data.body:
I saw a couple SO questions where a user mentioned errors they saw while debugging, but could not say which extension was responsible for the debugging. Someone should be able to figure it out, but I noticed that there isn't really good traceability from launch config to extension and vice versa. And you could have 5 extensions installed for X, with two different debuggers, and it's not obvious which you're using to debug. Example:

Here's my launch config, which extension am I using? Maybe hovering over the value here could show the extension display name.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19824410/ed53d3c4-9d23-11e6-80e3-3a166cf2f55a.png)

(Also opened #14681 to track this)-> Which debug types are supported? I have to read the readme (I'm not sure someone in this situation would look at this page, but it might be good to have the debug adapter "type" here).
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19824372/a30e97b8-9d23-11e6-968b-4c8ead9f8235.png)

data.title: Intellisense in package.json shows packages inconsistently
data.body:
From https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/13835#issuecomment-256813527,

When typing quickly, I'm selecting packages by initials (or something), but when I type slowly, I'm selecting packages by prefix:
1. Open package.json
2. Put the cursor in "dependencies"
3. ctrl+space, then esc (It doesn't repro unless the intellisense window has been shown on this line)
4. type `blu` quickly
5. The intellisense window appears again and I expect to see suggestions for all packages that match. Instead I only see "blackbaud-npi-datamart-ux", with the 'blu' highlighted. It's always this one package.

If you type `blu` more slowly, then it shows 'blu', 'blu-css', 'blu-generator' ...

Another example -
Typing "blah" quickly
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19823534/d9c6238a-9d1d-11e6-9b21-fe2ce214a419.png)

Slowly:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/19823537/e229d0d0-9d1d-11e6-8fe6-8dd5ce894e88.png)

The first type of fuzzy matching would be useful but it should be more consistent.

data.title: Implement tab close button configuration.
data.body:
Allows the user to enable/disable per-tab close buttons.

Addresses issue #10739.

data.title: No discoverable way to turn off a task in vscode once its started
data.body:
Version 1.6.1
Commit 9e4e44c19e393803e2b05fe2323cf4ed7e36880e
Date 2016-10-13T16:21:53.542Z
Shell 1.3.7
Renderer 52.0.2743.82
Node 6.5.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start task with Ctrl+Shift+B
2. How to turn it off. After an hour of searching. Kill VSCode, Restart it. 

This is a terrible user experience. Ctrl+Shift+B that turned off the task before worked totally fine.

There should be a big fat button in tasks window to kill the current task and restart it. Tooltips should show appropriate keyboard shortcut.

Also the info message shown when an already running task is run is not very useful. It should contain actions for remedies.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1018196/19822633/549303c6-9d19-11e6-8096-a182f1254815.png)

data.title: Keep previously opened files when opening a single file instead of clearing all files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

The issue at hand is when you close VSCode and you've had open tabs in it, opening a new file through windows explorer by double clicking it will cause VSCode to not restore your previous session on launch. Alternatively, if you closed VSCode, and then launch it normally without opening a file, it WILL restore your previous session. (I can make a video if my steps to reproduce are unclear).

Steps to Reproduce:
Use the following User settings

```
// Place your settings in this file to overwrite the default settings
{

    "workbench.editor.enablePreview": false,
    "window.openFilesInNewWindow": false,
    "window.reopenFolders": "all"
}
```
1. Open a few files in new tabs
2.  Close the window
3. Double click any file (.txt, .js, .html) from Windows explorer and open it with VSCode.
4. You will notice that your past tabs are cleared and your only tab is the file you opened

This ONLY happens if you launch VSCode by opening a new file (IE double clicking file in explorer, or right click open with, etc), if you simple click on VSCode it will restore your previous session.

data.title: Provide workbench.action.closePanel for keybindings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

I would like to bind the Esc key to the workbench.action.closePanel command, but when I do, VSCode says there is no such command. Looking at the code, I see a closePanel command defined in the same files (and seemingly the same way) as togglePanel, so I'm not sure why this doesn't work.

data.title: Unable to get installed npm package completions via IntelliSense
data.body:
Although I've created a default jsconfig.json file in the project root. Using VsCode version 1.6.1!

OS: ArchLinux

Steps to reproduce:
Initialize a demo project with npm init
Save lodash with npm install --save lodash
Open the folder in vscode
Initialize default jsconfig.json

data.title: Error installing extension behind corporate proxy
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Win7 SP1

Error message:

> write EPROTO 0:error:140770FC:SSL routines:SSL23_GET_SERVER_HELLO:unknown protocol:c:\jenkins\workspace\electron-win-ia32\vendor\node\deps\openssl\openssl\ssl\s23_clnt.c:794:

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Added http.proxy in workspace settings 
2. added http.proxyStrictSSL= false
3. Click to install an extension from marketplace

What I've tried:
1. Tried `npm config set registry http://registry.npmjs.org/`
2. Tried with and without "http.proxyStrictSSL": false
3. both npm and git works with the http.proxy settings, only VS code is not working

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3857964/19818580/5f8ba800-9d1e-11e6-8618-1b8f41a02c41.png)
